headline: Netflix price target lowered to $110 from $141 at Argus
summary: Argus lowered the firm’s price target on Netflix (NFLX) to $110 from $141 but keeps a Buy rating on the shares. The company’s agreement to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) is undoubtedly a bold move although shares have been punished in the aftermath as the market sees risk in Netflix getting involved in a bidding war with Paramount Skydance (PSKY) as well as around regulatory antitrust concerns, not to mention the potential for political interference, the analyst tells investors in a resear

headline: Is It Time To Reassess Paramount Skydance (PSKY) After The New Combined Structure?
summary: If you are wondering whether Paramount Skydance at US$11.78 is attractively priced or still risky, you are not alone. The stock has drawn attention from investors trying to work out what a fair value might look like. The share price return sits at 10.0% over the past year, even though the stock shows a 12.9% decline over 30 days and a 0.4% decline over 7 days. This can change how the risk and potential reward feel in the short term. Recent headlines around Paramount Skydance have focused on...

headline: Netflix says Paramount bid 'doesn't pass sniff test' as Warner battle intensifies, FT reports
summary: Netflix co-chief executive Greg Peters said the company is on track to win the ​backing of Warner Bros Discovery shareholders for its $82.7 ‌billion offer for the company's film and television studios, adding that Paramount's rival ‌bid "doesn't pass the sniff test", the Financial Times reported on Friday.  In an interview with the FT, Peters said only a "very small" number of WBD shares had been tendered in support ⁠of Paramount's hostile $108 ‌billion offer for the entire company.  Netflix, Warner Brothers and Paramount Skydance didn't immediately respond to Reuters ‍requests for comment outside regular business hours.

In an interview with the FT, Peters said only a "very small" number of WBD shares had been tendered in support ⁠of Paramount's hostile $108 ‌billion offer for the entire company.  Netflix, Warner Brothers and Paramount Skydance didn't immediately respond to Reuters ‍requests for comment outside regular business hours.
